issue.title: What is the structure of the final?
What is the structure of the final?

content.raw:
As a second alternative would be to have ROS on both sides. We can control the protocol and bandwidth based on what topics we publish and subscribe to.

I would also show the ROS on the OCU Earth side. On the Mars side you have ROS with IHMC nodes and competitor nodes. On the Earth side you show ROS with competitor nodes. The other ROS tools like RViz and Rqt would subscribe to the OCU competitor node topics and not reach across the wire to the Mars topics. There is still a little overhead to connect the OCU nodes and topics to register with the roscore but hopefully(will need to test) that is limited.

This is the direction that I am heading for now.

I am speculating that we will provide a number of nodes and a launch file to launch those nodes on the Mars side.
content.html:
As a second alternative would be to have ROS on both sides. We can control the protocol and bandwidth based on what topics we publish and subscribe to.

I would also show the ROS on the OCU Earth side. On the Mars side you have ROS with IHMC nodes and competitor nodes. On the Earth side you show ROS with competitor nodes. The other ROS tools like RViz and Rqt would subscribe to the OCU competitor node topics and not reach across the wire to the Mars topics. There is still a little overhead to connect the OCU nodes and topics to register with the roscore but hopefully(will need to test) that is limited.

This is the direction that I am heading for now.

I am speculating that we will provide a number of nodes and a launch file to launch those nodes on the Mars side.

issue.title: What is the structure of the final?

content.raw:
Yeah!  That's exactly what I have now, ROS on both sides.  My communications protocol packs up ROS packets (and zips them to save bandwidth) then sends it over to where I unpack it and re-publish it on the other side.  Of course, you don't have to run ROS on the OCU side, it just makes it feel more consistent.  

So I have two different ROS instances that are communicating with each other over the interwebs.
content.html:
Yeah! That's exactly what I have now, ROS on both sides. My communications protocol packs up ROS packets (and zips them to save bandwidth) then sends it over to where I unpack it and re-publish it on the other side. Of course, you don't have to run ROS on the OCU side, it just makes it feel more consistent.

So I have two different ROS instances that are communicating with each other over the interwebs.

issue.title: What is the structure of the final?

content.raw:
We are testing our communication between two computers as well but we are still not sure what topics will be available on the Mars side.
Obviously the ihmc and multisense topics, but will the tf topic be accessible?
content.html: We are testing our communication between two computers as well but we are still not sure what topics will be available on the Mars side. Obviously the ihmc and multisense topics, but will the tf topic be accessible?

issue.title: What is the structure of the final?

content.raw:
Ok, This raises a lot of questions for me that I would love clarification on.

1) We get to run team code on the field computer?  How much? What type?  Any limits? We had initially assumed not, but Jedediyah's image has a blue box over on the FC

2) Is our run expected to be fully autonomous or is there expected to be an operator (at the OCU) doing dynamic operations? We had assumed the operator basically said "go" and expectation was that our code would have to do all 3 tasks to completion without any human interaction.  If that is NOT the case then many of the problems become very different. Why am I spending so much time trying to get object recognition code working for the satellite dish if I can have an operator who can look at an image and just click on the dish to identify it.

3) If (1) is there is code on the FC and (2) is that the robot is fully autonomous what is the point of the OCU at all?  Everything runs on the FC and bandwidth and latency mean nothing.

Any chance we could have a clear description of the expected architecture? I am really confused and this is fundamental to the whole thing.  

-aric
content.html:
Ok, This raises a lot of questions for me that I would love clarification on.

1) We get to run team code on the field computer? How much? What type? Any limits? We had initially assumed not, but Jedediyah's image has a blue box over on the FC

2) Is our run expected to be fully autonomous or is there expected to be an operator (at the OCU) doing dynamic operations? We had assumed the operator basically said "go" and expectation was that our code would have to do all 3 tasks to completion without any human interaction. If that is NOT the case then many of the problems become very different. Why am I spending so much time trying to get object recognition code working for the satellite dish if I can have an operator who can look at an image and just click on the dish to identify it.

3) If (1) is there is code on the FC and (2) is that the robot is fully autonomous what is the point of the OCU at all? Everything runs on the FC and bandwidth and latency mean nothing.

Any chance we could have a clear description of the expected architecture? I am really confused and this is fundamental to the whole thing.

-aric

issue.title: What is the structure of the final?

content.html:
@aricstewart, there is some information in the first weekly FAQ from NineSigma. In the answer to Q5 they say:

"You can run code on the Field Computer (robot computer), and communicate with an OCU. It’s up to you to decide what code gets run where."

I think the expectation is that our control will be semi-autonomous in that we can have any level of interaction, but we will need to automate some tasks to have any hope of finishing each task within the allotted time.

issue.title: What is the structure of the final?

content.raw:
I agree with the concept of running ROS on both the local and remote computer. One illustrative concept is to run RVIZ locally connecting to the master node on the remote computer.

The question I have is can you run a ROS connection over the Internet? In particular what would be in the ROS network configuration setup? How do you get the IP address? I know in general how to do this but is it reliable connecting to a cloud system?
content.html:
I agree with the concept of running ROS on both the local and remote computer. One illustrative concept is to run RVIZ locally connecting to the master node on the remote computer.

The question I have is can you run a ROS connection over the Internet? In particular what would be in the ROS network configuration setup? How do you get the IP address? I know in general how to do this but is it reliable connecting to a cloud system?

issue.title: What is the structure of the final?

content.raw:
If this is suppose to simulate a Mars mission then I would think that Val will be using ROS to complete the mission and transmit telemetry data back to the command computer. The time lag will be significant anyway
and you may not be able complete the tasks if your strategy is to rely on teleoperation alone.

As Dan would be the expert on this subject, issues that might arise in a space mission would be simulated back on Earth and new instructions would be transmitted to the vehicle.
content.html:
If this is suppose to simulate a Mars mission then I would think that Val will be using ROS to complete the mission and transmit telemetry data back to the command computer. The time lag will be significant anyway and you may not be able complete the tasks if your strategy is to rely on teleoperation alone.

As Dan would be the expert on this subject, issues that might arise in a space mission would be simulated back on Earth and new instructions would be transmitted to the vehicle.

issue.title: What is the structure of the final?

content.raw:
I think that the time lag is going to be very limiting. I do not see how tele-op is going to work. semi-autonomous seems like the way to go. Use most of the bandwidth to receive telemetry and then send an occasional command to the robot.

Here is a little tidbit that may be of interest. Check out item 2.3 from this page about tf. http://wiki.ros.org/tf/Design
content.html:
I think that the time lag is going to be very limiting. I do not see how tele-op is going to work. semi-autonomous seems like the way to go. Use most of the bandwidth to receive telemetry and then send an occasional command to the robot.

Here is a little tidbit that may be of interest. Check out item 2.3 from this page about tf. http://wiki.ros.org/tf/Design
